content: The Act may be cited as the "Asthma Awareness, Education and Treatment Act of 1999". The Congress finds that asthma affects millions of Americans, including children, and is the most common chronic respiratory disease in children. The prevalence of pediatric asthma has increased significantly over the years. The prevalence of pediatric asthma has increased significantly over the years, affecting millions of Americans, especially children. Asthma accounts for 25 percent of school absenteeism and is the third leading cause of preventable hospitalizations. The prevalence of asthma is higher in women than in men, and greater in low-income families. In women, asthma prevalence is higher than in men (5.6% vs 5.1%). Low-income families have a greater prevalence of asthma, with 79.2 out of 1,000 individuals under 45 in families earning less than $10,000 affected. In 1997, over 5,000 Americans died from asthma attacks, with African Americans having an average of 38.5 deaths from asthma between 1993 and 1995. In families with an annual income of $20,000 to $35,000, 53.6 out of 1,000 individuals under 45 have asthma. In 1997, more than 5,000 Americans died from asthma attacks. The average number of deaths from asthma for African Americans was 38.5 deaths per million individuals, while for Caucasians it was 15.1 deaths per million. Asthma costs the United States over $12 billion annually, with rising prevalence leading to higher future costs. The asthma death rate is significantly higher for African Americans compared to Caucasians, with African Americans being five times more likely to seek care at an emergency room. The death rate is four times higher among African American children and two times higher among all African Americans. SEC. 5. TAX CREDIT FOR DONATIONS OF PEST CONTROL AND CLIMATE CONTROL SERVICES. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide a tax credit for donations of pest control and climate control services. The tax credit for donations of pest control and climate control services is equal to 10 percent of the costs incurred by the taxpayer in providing qualified services without charge. During the taxable year, a tax credit is available for providing qualified pest control and climate control services without charge in public housing or multifamily residential rental properties with at least 75% low-income occupants. The Director of the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute will identify federal programs for asthma, develop a federal response plan, and submit recommendations to Congress for improving coordination of asthma-related activities. The National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee will include a representative from the Department of Housing and Urban Development to strengthen coordination of federal asthma-related activities. Authorization of $5,000,000 from NIH funds for the National Asthma Education Prevention Program from 2000 to 2004. SEC. 8. COMPILATION OF DATA BY CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in consultation with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee, conducts local asthma surveillance activities to collect data on asthma prevalence, severity, and management quality through telephone surveys and health care facility specific surveillance. They also compile and annually publish this data. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in collaboration with the National Asthma Education Prevention Program Coordinating Committee, conducts local asthma surveillance activities. This includes telephone surveys to collect household data on asthma burden and health care facility specific surveillance to gather data on asthma prevalence, severity, and quality of care. They compile and publish data annually on the prevalence of childhood asthma in each state and the childhood mortality rate associated with asthma nationally and in each state.
